Note: One of the hymns presents Gaia as the life-sustaining, ever-fruitful Earth.
Here, Gaia is not narratively active. She’s invoked as a metaphysical constant, not a character.
In the Theogony, Gaia is a protagonist-level cosmic agent, the true architect of the generational succession myth.
In the Theogony, Uranus is the first tyrant, the first sky, and the architectural upper boundary of the cosmos.
Here Uranus is mentioned onliy once, when Hesiod gestures to the old cosmogonic order.
Since Orphic tradition contains several competing cosmologies, here Uranus shows up in radically different roles depending on the variant.
Theogony is a source of Cronus' primary canonical narrative. Everything definitive about him — genealogy, character, succession — comes from here.
Here Cronus is the eponym of the Golden Age, not a character. Hesiod uses him to contrast the moral decline of the Iron Age.
Cronus appears a lot and his nature shifts dramatically depending on the variant of Orphic cosmology.
This is the main canonical source for Rhea, among other deities. Her role here is tightly tied to the divine succession myth.
To sum up different roles of Rhea depending on the Orphic cosmology, Rhea is a mystical Mother-Goddess of the Olympians tied to the cosmic order and initiation rites.
Here Rhea is mentioned as a mother of many Gods, though doesn't have a narative role.

Theogony presents Zeus as a ruler who gains power through conflict, alliances, and shrewd political maneuvering. The poem lays out his genealogy, narrates his rise over Cronus and the Titans, and portrays him as the stabilizer of cosmic order.
Here, Zeus appears as the commanding divine power who steers the war’s fate through direct interventions, negotiations with other gods, and decisive control over the battlefield.
In Odyssey Zeus is depicted as the high overseer who authorizes Athena’s aid, enforces divine justice, and governs the long return and final reconciliation of Odysseus.

Here, Zeus appears as the moral governor of human life, dispensing justice, punishing corruption, rewarding fairness, shaping the Ages of Man, and orchestrating the Pandora episode as retribution for human transgression.

The Orphic tradition reimagines Zeus as a metaphysical totality who swallows Phanes, absorbs all divinity into himself, recreates the cosmos from within, and stands in the Orphic succession as the all-encompassing progenitor of Dionysus and ultimately of humankind.
In Protagoras, Zeus functions as the mythic civilizer whose bestowal of justice and modesty is reshaped by Plato into a philosophical account of the origins of social virtue and political order.

In the Republic, Zeus appears only symbolically, serving as a residual theological image of cosmic justice that Plato integrates into a metaphysical vision of lawful order and the structure of the just city.

In Phaedrus, Zeus leads the divine chariot in a mythic depiction that becomes the philosophical model for the soul’s ascent toward the Forms, translating an old god-king into an archetype of rational governance.

In the Symposium, Zeus splits the original double-bodied humans, providing a mythological substrate that Plato converts into a philosophical exploration of eros as the engine of cosmic and intellectual order.
In Prometheus Bound, Zeus is a young, autocratic tyrant whose brutal punishment of Prometheus and fear of prophecy reveal an unstable, pre-ethical phase of divine kingship.

Here Herodotus portrays Zeus as a Panhellenic oath-god and political legitimizer, rationalized and syncretized across cultures—from Zeus-Ammon to euhemeristic genealogies—to anchor justice and authority in the historical world.
In Cleanthes’ Hymn to Zeus, Zeus is exalted as the single cosmic Logos—the rational, providential force that orders the universe and subsumes all other gods into his universal law.
Theogony contains the fullest account of Typhon as final challenger to Zeus’ sovereignty.

In the Histories, Typhon appears only as a comparative and interpretive figure—identified with the Egyptian god Set and invoked in explanations of winds and natural phenomena—reflecting Herodotus’ rationalizing, cross-cultural approach to myth
Here, Typhon is evoked poetically as the buried monster beneath Etna, a symbolic embodiment of chaotic force whose suppression showcases Zeus’ cosmic order and the aetiology of volcanic power.

One of the Homeric Hymns presents Demeter as the central figure in a full narrative of loss, wrath, cosmic disruption, and ritual foundation—one of the most developed and emotionally powerful depictions of Greek deities.
Demeter in Theogony is a genealogical goddess whose significance is acknowledged but not narratively explored.
Here, Europa is mentioned only once, as part of a genealogical list.

Herodotus treats Europa as a Phoenician princess in a rationalized tale of reciprocal abductions between Greeks and Asians, stripping the myth of its divine elements and using it for cultural analysis.
Pindar evokes Europa in rich mythic imagery, celebrating her abduction by Zeus-as-bull and her role as the noble progenitor of Crete’s legendary rulers.
In the Iliad, Apollo is a decisive divine actor who sends the plague, aids the Trojans, and intervenes violently in battle as the dominant god of plague, prophecy, and archery.
Here, Apollo functions primarily as a ritual and symbolic presence whose domains—prophecy and archery—frame key events without involving him as an acting character.
In Theogony, Apollo is a foundational Olympian defined by genealogy and divine function—prophecy, music, and order—without narrative development.
The text depicts Apollo as the prophetic, harmonizing patron of aristocratic excellence and civic foundations, invoked as the divine guarantor of order and fate.
Here, Apollo emerges as a charismatic, central deity whose birth, slaying of Python, and founding of Delphi define him as the authoritative god of prophecy and sacred order.
The texts portrays Apollo as a marginal divine figure invoked only as part of the poem’s moral-religious background without narrative action.
In the Oresteia, Apollo is the divine architect of Orestes’ matricide and his legal defender, embodying a shift from blood-vengeance to a patriarchal, court-based conception of justice.
In Prometheus Bound, Apollo appears only in allusion as the god of prophecy whose lineage and oracular authority underscore the long arc of fate that even Zeus must ultimately submit to.
In Antigone, Apollo stands behind Tiresias’ prophecy as the divine voice condemning Creon, representing the higher moral and religious order Creon has broken.
Here, Apollo appears primarily as the power behind the Delphic oracles, shaping real political decisions and historical events through prophetic authority.
In Oedipus Rex, Apollo is the dominant divine presence whose plague, prophecies, and oracular revelations drive every turn of the plot and enforce the tragic unraveling of Oedipus’s fate.
In Bacchae, Apollo is mentioned only to contrast his sober order with Dionysus’ ecstatic power, highlighting the play’s polarity without taking part in the action.
In Protagoras, Apollo appears only implicitly as the god of traditional civic wisdom, forming a religious backdrop to the dialogue’s challenge to inherited authority.
The text invokes Apollo as the god of prophetic madness, exemplifying the divine form of inspiration that legitimizes the dialogue’s treatment of mania as a positive philosophical force.
In the Republic, Apollo appears as the cultural symbol of Delphic wisdom, measure, and moral authority, quietly grounding the dialogue’s concern with harmony and ordered knowledge.
In Memorabilia, Apollo functions as the divine legitimizer of Socrates’ wisdom and conduct, his Delphic oracles framing Socrates’ life as a mission sanctioned by the god.
In Hellenica, Apollo appears through politically influential Delphic oracles that shape historical decisions, reflecting his status as a central public authority in Greek statecraft.
The text invokes Apollo as the sacred guardian of Delphi and a divine witness to political wrongdoing, reinforcing Demosthenes’ charge of violated oaths and corruption.
In the Iliad, Hermes appears chiefly as the gentle, diplomatic guide who escorts Priam to Achilles, embodying divine mediation and safe passage in a brutal war.
In the Odyssey, Hermes acts as Zeus’s messenger and Odysseus’s practical helper, freeing him from Calypso and arming him against Circe with characteristic cunning and divine know-how.
Here, Hermes appears primarily in genealogical form as the son of Zeus and Maia, his functions sketched but without narrative development.
In Works and Days, Hermes appears only as a minor agent in the creation of Pandora and the enforcement of moral order, with no narrative role.
In the Homeric Hymns, Hermes stars in a full narrative of divine trickery, inventiveness, and reconciliation—defining his identity as the clever, boundary-crossing mediator among the gods.
In Pindar’s Odes, Hermes is invoked as the herald, guide, and patron of skillful success, a divine emblem of fortunate cunning and athletic excellence.
In Prometheus Bound, Hermes appears as Zeus’s harsh enforcer, delivering threats to Prometheus and embodying the regime’s authoritarian power.
In Herodotus, Hermes appears in ethnographic parallels, genealogies, and cultic references, functioning as a cross-cultural marker.
In Iliad, Ares is the only Olympian god wounded by a mortal in open battle (Diomedes), establishing his paradoxical nature as both god of war and the least effective divine warrior.
Ares does not appear in the main narrative but appears in the internal tale of the bard Demodocus.
In the Theogony, Ares appears only as a genealogical figure, named as the son of Zeus and Hera without any narrative development or characterization.
One of the hymns contains a rare positive portrayal of Ares as a moralizing deity who can grant self-control, indicating a much more philosophical, possibly Orphic-tinged reinterpretation.
Pindar uses Ares primarily as a metaphorical force of civic identity, linking warfare to aristocratic excellence rather than battlefield narrative.
Ares is part of the ideological apparatus of Zeus’ tyranny—an extremely rare depiction where he functions as an enforcer of cosmic order rather than battlefield chaos.

In the Histories, Ares appears as a comparative, ethnographic label—Herodotus effectively Hellenizes foreign war-gods, such as the Scythians’ own blade-worshipped deity, by calling them “Ares,” rather than presenting the Greek god as an actual narrative figure.
In the Encomium of Helen, Ares appears only as an illustration of divine causality, part of Gorgias’ argument that god-sent forces absolve humans of blame.
In the Symposium, Ares appears only as a symbolic counterpoint to Aphrodite, representing discord within discussions of harmony and eros.
In the Republic, Ares appears only as an example of the morally flawed divine portrayals that Plato seeks to censor, symbolizing the kind of destructive behavior unfit for the ideal city.
In the Orphic Hymns, Ares is invoked as a fiery cosmic power of war whose destructive force the poet seeks to restrain and transform into peace.
In the Iliad, Athena is a dominant divine force who repeatedly intervenes in battle and strategy, championing the Achaeans through disciplined, rational martial power.
Here, Athena is the primary divine guide who engineers Odysseus’s return and Telemachus’s maturation, embodying wisdom, strategy, and civic restoration.
In the Theogony, Athena appears in her dramatic birth scene as the armed daughter of Zeus and Metis, establishing her as a foundational Olympian of wisdom and martial craft.
In Works and Days, Athena appears only in passing as a civilizing goddess who grants skill in crafts and orderly work.
In on of the Hymns, Athena receives a brief but concentrated praise that celebrates her as the wise, warlike guardian of cities and craftsmanship.
In Pindar’s Odes, Athena is invoked as the patron of heroes, cities, and skilled excellence, a divine emblem of intelligence, craft, and aristocratic virtue.
This is the earliest extant text portraying Athena as founder of a judicial institution, fusing myth and the history of Athenian law.
In the Histories, Athena appears as the civic and protective goddess of Athens, invoked in temples, omens, and wartime narratives.
In the Orphic Hymns, Athena is praised as a cosmic guardian of wisdom, war-craft, purity, and skill, receiving one of the most elaborate ritual portraits in Orphic tradition
In the Iliad, Minos appears as the divinely favored early king of Crete and the ancestor legitimizing Idomeneus’ heroic lineage.
In the Odyssey, Minos is depicted as a stern judge of the dead in the Underworld, reinforcing his legendary status as a just lawgiver.
In the Theogony, Minos appears solely as one of Europa’s sons by Zeus, establishing his divine paternity.
In the Hymn to Apollo, Minos appears as the archetypal king of Crete, anchoring the island’s religious prestige.
Pindar presents Minos as a divinely instructed ruler whose authority derives directly from Zeus.
Herodotus treats Minos as an early historical-mythical king whose naval power shaped the Aegean.
Gorgias invokes Minos as an example of Zeus-born nobility in his rhetorical re-framing of Helen’s story.
In Protagoras, Minos is praised as a paradigm of early divine-sanctioned justice and legislation.
In The Republic, Minos functions as a cosmic judge in Plato’s eschatological myth.
Plato uses Minos as an analogy for inherited legitimacy, indicating Minos had become a byword for royal authority.
This text gives the clearest philosophical depiction of Minos as the arbiter of morally weighty souls.
Mirabilia refers to Minos only in scattered anecdotal notices connecting him to the legendary antiquities of Crete.
In the Theogony, Perseus appears as the heroic slayer of Medusa and the ancestor whose line leads to Heracles.
The only major poetic corpus that transforms Perseus into a paradigm for athletic virtue, not just heroic violence.
In the Orphic fragments, Perseus appears only in scattered genealogical references without narrative detail.
In Mirabilia, Perseus appears sporadically in marvel-stories associated with Libya and the aftermath of the Gorgon’s death.
In the Iliad, “Linus” appears only as the name of a traditional lamentation-song sung by harvesters, not as an active mythic character.
In Pindar, Theseus serves as a heroic, semi-foundational figure whose exploits exemplify aristocratic virtue and divine favor.
In Hippolytus, Theseus is a central tragic figure whose rash paternal judgment drives the drama’s catastrophe.
In the Encomium, Theseus is invoked as a heroic precedent to illustrate Helen’s irresistible attraction and mitigate her blame.
In The Republic, Theseus briefly appears as a paradigm of heroic companionship and civic virtue.
In Gorgias, Theseus is invoked in passing as an exemplar of righteous governance and noble character.
In Phaedrus, Theseus appears through the myth of Phaedra and Hippolytus as an emblem of erotic catastrophe.
In Phaedo, Theseus functions as a culturally foundational hero whose commemorative ship frames the timing of Socrates’ death.
In History of Animals, Theseus appears only as the legendary subduer of the Marathonian bull in a zoological aside.
In Politics, Theseus is portrayed as the legendary founder who unified Attica and laid the groundwork for later political order.
In Mirabilia, Theseus appears intermittently in marvel-stories connected to the Marathonian bull and the Cretan Labyrinth.
Pindar uses Jason, especially in Pythian 4, as a divinely guided heroic founder whose Argonautic quest mirrors and legitimizes the noble lineage of the ode’s patrons.
In Medea, Jason appears not as the glorious Argonaut but as a calculating betrayer whose self-serving rationalizations ignite Medea’s fury and expose the fragility of heroic and patriarchal ideals.
In the Orphic Fragments, Orpheus appears as the inspired seer-poet whose revelations transmit the secret cosmogony and mystical theology of the Orphic tradition.
The Gold Tablets contain Orphic afterlife theology but never mention Orpheus by name — his presence is doctrinal, not textual.
In Pindar, Orpheus appears as the archetypal divinely inspired singer whose musical authority parallels the noble order Pindar praises.
In Protagoras, Orpheus is invoked as a foundational moral educator whose poetry shapes early Greek paideia.
In the Symposium, Orpheus is used as a negative exemplum — a poet who tried to retrieve his beloved through craft rather than courage and thus failed.
In the Republic, Orpheus is both a symbol of untrustworthy poetic mythmaking and a mythic soul whose fate illustrates the perils of poetic imagination.
In the Iliad, Heracles appears as a paradigmatic earlier hero whose labors and violence set a standard for mortal excellence.
In the Odyssey, Heracles is a unique semi-divine figure split between Olympus and Hades, symbolizing extreme suffering and eventual apotheosis.
In the Theogony, Heracles is the son of Zeus whose labors earn him full divinity and a place on Olympus.
In Works and Days, Heracles is brifly mentioned as a destructive force within Hesiod’s myth of the heroic age.
In the Homeric Hymns, Heracles is celebrated as a mighty, divinely sired hero uplifted by Zeus.
In Pindar, Heracles is a foundational hero whose deeds legitimize aristocratic virtue and sacred institutions (Olympic Games).
In Prometheus Bound, Heracles is the future liberator whose advent ends Prometheus’s torment.
In Herodotus, Heracles is a cross-cultural deity whose Greek form is presented as derivative of Egyptian cult.
In Memorabilia, Heracles becomes a moral exemplar embodying deliberate choice of virtue over pleasure.
In Gorgias, Heracles appears as Callicles’ model of natural strength and domination.
In The Republic, Heracles is a mythic figure appearing in Plato’s eschatological storytelling.
In Protagoras, Heracles serves as an example of traditional heroic virtue embedded in Greek education.
In Phaedrus, Heracles is used as an example of divine–heroic love relationships.
In the Orphic fragments, Heracles appears in alternative cosmogonies and heroic genealogies.
In Metaphysics, Heracles is invoked metaphorically to represent arduous intellectual labor.
In the Ethics, Heracles exemplifies heroic virtue and extreme endurance.
In Politics, Heracles is referenced as an early heroic founder associated with kingship models.
In Rhetoric, Heracles functions as a universally recognized heroic reference point.
In the Theogony, Medea appears as the divine-born daughter of Aeëtes and the companion of Jason, playing a genealogical role as mother of Medeios.
In Pindar, Medea appears as a wise, prophetic helper figure whose foreknowledge guides the Argonauts and anchors a foundational prophecy for Cyrene.
In Euripides’ Medea, she is the central tragic protagonist whose betrayal by Jason unleashes her calculated, divine-tinged revenge culminating in the murder of their children.
In Hippolytus, Medea appears only as a cautionary emblem of the catastrophic power of passion.
In the Histories, Medea appears in a rationalizing account of mythic East–West abductions, used to explain the deep origins of conflict between Asia and Greece.
In the Iliad, Achilles is the epic’s central hero whose wrath, grief, and return to battle shape the entire narrative structure.
In the Odyssey, Achilles appears as a ghost who rejects his heroic glory in favor of the value of ordinary life.
In Works and Days, Achilles belongs to the vanished heroic race destroyed in the wars at Thebes and Troy.
In Pindar, Achilles is the supreme model of heroic excellence whose lineage and aretē validate aristocratic ideals.
The Orphic fragments reference Achilles only in scattered genealogical or eschatological contexts, not as a narrative figure.
In Prometheus Bound, Achilles appears indirectly through Prometheus’ prophecy of Thetis’s powerful future son.
In Histories, Achilles appears as a hero-cult figure only because Herodotus reframes what was likely a native Scythian warrior cult through a Greek, Hellenizing lens.
In Thucydides, Achilles is used as a benchmark for assessing the inflated military claims of epic tradition.
In Protagoras, Achilles is examined as a moral case study from Homer used in educational critique.
In the Symposium, Achilles is the supreme example of devoted, sacrificial love.
In Gorgias, Achilles serves as an exemplar of fearless, principled heroism.
In the Republic, Achilles is a major case study in poetic ethics and the transformation of heroic identity in the afterlife.
In Phaedrus, Achilles is held up as the divinely honored lover who died for his beloved.
In Memorabilia, Achilles appears as a traditional paradigm of heroic virtue and discipline.
In the Rhetoric, Achilles illustrates paradigmatic emotional states used in persuasive argument.
In Politics, Achilles is cited as an example of heroic, pre-political kingship.
In the Poetics, Achilles serves as the exemplary epic hero whose character reveals core principles of dramatic construction.
In the Iliad, Agamemnon is the authoritative yet arrogant high king whose quarrel with Achilles drives the epic’s core drama.
In the Odyssey, Agamemnon’s murder becomes the paradigm warning about the dangers awaiting returning warriors.
In the Theogony, Agamemnon appears simply as a genealogical descendant of Atreus.
In Pindar, Agamemnon appears as a traditional heroic king invoked to glorify aristocratic lineage and epic valor.
In the Oresteia, Agamemnon is the pivotal murdered king whose death sets in motion the cycle of vengeance and ultimate foundation of civic justice.
Herodotus analyzes Agamemnon as a historical problem, not a mythic hero, marking one of the first attempts to rationalize Trojan War leadership historically and geopolitically.
In Thucydides, Agamemnon is a historical-like figure whose authority is explained through political and naval power rather than mythic charisma.
In Protagoras, Agamemnon is examined as a didactic figure illustrating failures of leadership.
In the Symposium, Agamemnon appears only as a stock example of heroic mortal renown.
In Gorgias, Agamemnon is cited as one of the powerful rulers whose crimes are revealed and judged after death.
In the Republic, Agamemnon is invoked both as a problematic Homeric king and a soul that chooses a bird’s life to escape human leadership.
In Phaedrus, Agamemnon appears only as a passing mythic reference within a catalog of heroic examples.
In the Rhetoric, Agamemnon is a standard mythic case used to illustrate emotional and argumentative patterns.
In Politics, Agamemnon exemplifies pre-polis heroic kingship based on lineage and prestige.
In the Poetics, Agamemnon is a principal example of a tragic figure whose story encapsulates the ideal structure of reversal and recognition.
In the Athenian Constitution, Agamemnon is referenced as part of the early heroic framework of Greek kingship.
In the Iliad, Odysseus stands out as the clever, eloquent strategist whose intelligence balances Achilles’ brute force.
In the Odyssey, Odysseus is the epic’s core figure whose cunning, endurance, and desire for home structure the entire poem.
In Pindar, Odysseus is a double-edged heroic figure—admired for cleverness yet morally suspect for deceitful success.
In the Oresteia, Odysseus appears briefly as part of the background Trojan War mythology.
In Herodotus, Odysseus arises as the prototype of clever fictional invention whose narrative elements Herodotus critiques or rationalizes.
In Thucydides, Odysseus appears only as part of the broader mythic tradition whose reliability is questioned.
In Protagoras, Odysseus becomes a test case for how Homeric characters exemplify or fail to exemplify virtue in educational contexts.
In Gorgias, Odysseus is an example of a powerful mortal whose soul undergoes posthumous judgment.
In the Republic, Odysseus is both a criticized model of cunning and the soul that chooses the most modest life in the afterlife.
In Phaedrus, Odysseus is a fleeting mythic reference embedded within lists of heroic figures.
In the Rhetoric, Odysseus illustrates paradigmatic cleverness and persuasive strategy.
In Politics, Odysseus exemplifies early monarchic household-based kingship.
In the Poetics, Odysseus is a core example of a well-constructed epic character whose adventures illustrate the principles of plot.
In the Athenian Constitution, Odysseus appears briefly as part of early heroic structures of authority.
In Antigone, Oedipus functions as the inherited curse whose legacy defines the tragedy of his children.
In Herodotus, Oedipus appears only as a cultural reference point for well-known Greek tragic narratives.
In Oedipus Rex, Oedipus is the central tragic hero whose quest for truth destroys him as he discovers he is his father’s killer and his mother’s husband.
Oedipus is cited as example of someone who commited terrible deeds unknowingly and is used to illustrate moral evaluation after death.
In the Rhetoric, Oedipus illustrates paradigmatic tragic ignorance and unintended crime.
In Politics, Oedipus serves as an example of early hereditary kingship within mythic genealogies.
In the Poetics, Oedipus is Aristotle’s supreme example of the perfect tragic structure built around recognition and reversal.
In Theocritus’ Idylls, Oedipus is mentioned only as a brief poetic allusion to tragic suffering.
In Mirabilia, Oedipus appears only in passing as the solver of the Sphinx’s riddle in a marvels context.
In the Apology, Musaeus appears as one of the legendary poet-sages whom Socrates looks forward to meeting after death, symbolizing ancient inspired wisdom.

In the Republic, Musaeus appears in two distinct ways: first, as a mystery-poet criticized for offering deceptive ritual salvation; and second, in the Myth of Er, as a soul who chooses a peaceful contemplative existence befitting a poet-sage.
In the Bacchae, Lycurgus appears as a cautionary mythic opponent of Dionysus whose brutal punishment exemplifies the fate of those who resist the god.
In Against Meidias, Lycurgus is invoked as a mythological example of hubris punished by divine justice, reinforcing Demosthenes’ argument against Meidias’ insolence.
In the Rhetoric, Aristotle cites Sappho as a model of masterful emotional expression and poetic vividness.
In the Politics, Sappho appears as an exemplary poet cited in discussions of musical education and the ethical function of poetry.
In Protagoras, Thales is listed among the ancient sages whose maxims form the earliest Greek wisdom tradition.
In the Republic, Thales exemplifies the philosopher absorbed in contemplation and blind to practical affairs.
In the Theaetetus, Thales again represents the prototype of the star-gazing philosopher detached from everyday concerns.
In De Anima, Thales is credited with an early proto-scientific theory that soul is defined by the capacity to cause motion.
In the Rhetoric, Thales exemplifies the philosopher who can become wealthy at will by applying foresight, though he normally chooses not to.
In the Metaphysics, Thales is portrayed as the earliest philosopher who identified a single material principle (water) as the origin of all things.
In the Politics, Thales exemplifies the wise man who contributes insight to political life without engaging directly in rule.
In the Rhetoric, Alcaeus is cited as a model of powerful lyric expression, especially concerning political strife and emotional intensity.
In the Politics, Alcaeus appears as a historical witness whose poetry documents the nature of stasis and tyranny on Lesbos.
In the Poetics, Alcaeus is cited as a representative lyric poet used to illustrate distinctions between poetic genres.
In the Metaphysics, Anaximander is presented as the early cosmologist who first posited the infinite apeiron as the origin of all things and the basis of cosmic justice.
In the Physics, Anaximander is cited as the philosopher who proposed the apeiron as an eternal, divine source responsible for generating, sustaining, and dissolving worlds.
In the Histories, Pythagoras appears as a transmitter of Egyptian ideas on purification and reincarnation.
In the Hippocratic Corpus, Pythagoras is invoked as the leader of speculative, number-based theories rejected by empirical medicine.
In the Theaetetus, Pythagoras appears indirectly through mention of the Pythagorean school devoted to mathematics and communal discipline.
In the Phaedo, Pythagoras is a background authority whose doctrines of soul and reincarnation inform Socrates’ metaphysics.
In De Anima, Aristotle explicitly rejects the Pythagorean claim that the soul is a harmony or ratio of bodily elements.
In the Rhetoric, Pythagoras is cited as a source of moral and proverbial wisdom used in persuasive speech.
In the Metaphysics, Aristotle treats Pythagoras and the Pythagoreans as originators of the doctrine that numbers constitute the structure of reality.
In the Harmonics, Pythagoras stands for the mathematical school of music theory that Aristoxenus opposes.
In the Theaetetus, Heraclitus is the leading exponent of total flux, whose doctrines are used to undermine stable knowledge.
In the Phaedo, Heraclitus appears as a source for the doctrine that opposites arise from one another.
In the Sophist, Heraclitus represents the camp that denies stability, forming one pole of the dialogue’s metaphysical opposition.
In the Republic, Heraclitus is the archetype of the obscure thinker whose riddling style contrasts with philosophical clarity.
In De Anima, Heraclitus is cited for defining the soul as a fiery, ever-moving substance.
In the Rhetoric, Heraclitus exemplifies the obscure, overly enigmatic style speakers should avoid.
In the Metaphysics, Heraclitus is the central representative of flux and contradiction, forming a major pole of pre-Socratic metaphysics.
In the Physics, Heraclitus represents the doctrine that reality is ceaseless motion governed by a rational principle (logos).
In the Nicomachean Ethics, Heraclitus’ river metaphor is briefly used to illustrate instability in moral character.
In the Parmenides, Zeno is a major character who presents and explains his paradoxes as a defense of Eleatic monism.
In the Theaetetus, Zeno is cited as the master of reductio arguments used to expose contradictions in ordinary beliefs.
In the Sophist, Zeno is invoked as the exemplar of paradoxical reasoning that forces contradictions on views about plurality and motion.
In the Rhetoric, Zeno appears as a model of paradoxical reasoning used to illustrate subtle argumentative tricks.
In the Metaphysics, Zeno is cited as the author of paradoxes designed to refute plurality and motion, serving as a foil for Aristotelian substance theory.
In the Physics, Aristotle provides the classical critique of Zeno’s paradoxes of motion, making this the most substantial ancient discussion of Zeno.
In the Organon, Zeno’s style of paradoxical refutation serves as a model of certain sophistical or dialectical techniques.
In De Anima, Philolaus appears as a Pythagorean thinker who defines the soul as a harmony, a doctrine Aristotle critiques.
In the Metaphysics, Philolaus is treated as a central Pythagorean cosmologist who grounded the universe in the interplay of limit and unlimited, structured by number.
In the Physics, Philolaus represents the Pythagorean attempt to explain nature through fundamental opposites and numerical structure.
In the Rhetoric, Philolaus appears as an example of overly technical philosophical style that obscures meaning.
The longest sustained philosophical monologue of “Socratic” philosophy in antiquity, even though the ideas are more Platonic than historical.
Socrates delivers his only extended meditation on divine madness, including the myth of the charioteer soul.
The only surviving ancient defense of Socrates written by someone who knew him personally.
Provides the only extended eyewitness narrative of Socrates’ final hours.
This is the only cosmological dialogue in which Socrates is a character.
Letter 7 claims that Socrates’ death was the turning point of Plato’s political disillusionment.
This is the only explicit mention of Socrates in the corpus of a professional rhetorician who rejected the sophistic label.
Socrates is used politically as an example of Athenian error—a rare case of a philosopher entering political oratory.
The Odyssey is famously situated as the narrative aftermath of the Iliad, repeatedly naming Iliadic characters, events, and episodes.
Works and Days plugs the Trojan War (Iliad’s event-space) into Hesiod’s Five Races anthropology, assuming the war’s cultural significance without naming the poem.
Parmenides retains Homeric-style mythic framing in order to overturn traditional cosmology, creating an indirect conceptual link to the Iliad’s divine world.
Pindar’s mythic exempla depend heavily on Iliadic heroic narratives even though he never names the poem directly.
The Oresteia directly cites and dramatizes key Iliadic events and characters.
Empedocles reworks Homeric cosmology into a philosophical dualism, creating a conceptual dialogue with the Iliad.
Herodotus explicitly engages, critiques, and reinterprets Homeric (including Iliadic) traditions as quasi-historical material.
Thucydides explicitly critiques Homer’s military descriptions and uses the Trojan War as a baseline historical model.
Protagoras explicitly discusses Homer as a moral authority, directly tying the dialogue to the Iliad’s cultural role.
Gorgias explicitly cites Homer and uses epic myth to frame Socrates’ eschatological argument.
The Republic explicitly critiques Illiadic depictions of the gods and Homer himself as the first educator of Greece.
Aristotle explicitly quotes verses from the Iliad as the prime model for stylistic excellence.
Aristotle uses the Iliad as the definitive model of epic structure, quoting and analyzing it more than any other work in the Poetics.
Aristotle critiques traditional poetic cosmology inherited from Homer, but avoids naming Homer explicitly here.
Physics indirectly engages with Homeric divine causality in its critique of poetical explanations of natural motion.
Aristotle cites Homer directly in zoological contexts, using Iliadic vocabulary as evidence for natural descriptions.
Empedocles gives a philosophical reconstruction of the cosmic order that the Odyssey dramatizes, producing indirect comparative connection only.
Herodotus explicitly cites Homer and indirectly engages the Odyssey through Helen’s Egyptian story and through ethnographic travel-narrative parallels.
Gorgias indirectly engages with the Odyssean portrayal of Helen by offering a philosophical defense of her actions.
Protagoras explicitly discusses Homer as educator, indirectly invoking Odyssean material as part of the poetic canon under debate.
Gorgias explicitly cites Homer and builds its final eschatological scene on the Odyssean underworld.
The Republic explicitly cites Odysseus, quotes Odyssey scenes, and builds philosophical arguments around Homeric material.
Phaedo reworks the Odyssean underworld into a philosophical cosmology, forming a strong indirect and comparative link.
Phaedrus does not quote Homer but implicitly models its soul-journey narrative on Odyssean wandering structures.
Rhetoric explicitly quotes Homeric (including Odyssean) lines and uses Odysseus’ rhetorical prowess as a model.
Poetics directly analyzes and praises the Odyssey as the model of epic plot unity, providing explicit references.
Metaphysics indirectly responds to the divine-causal worldview central to the Odyssey, critiquing its theological assumptions.
History of Animals explicitly draws on Homeric (including Odyssean) animal imagery as authoritative natural description.
Mirabilia explicitly treats Odyssean monsters and marvels as real-world wonders, creating a direct encyclopedic connection to the Odyssey.
Works and Days explicitly builds on Theogony’s divine genealogy and reuses major myths (Prometheus, Pandora) to construct an ethical worldview.
The Homeric Hymns depend entirely on Theogony’s genealogical structure, implicitly reaffirming Hesiod’s divine family tree.
Pindar adopts Hesiod’s divine order and mythic genealogies as the backbone of his theistic framework for heroic praise.
The Oresteia dramatizes Hesiod’s theogonic divine justice system, especially the genealogy and function of Zeus and the Erinyes.
The Orphic fragments interact with Theogony by reworking, expanding, or replacing its divine genealogy and primordial cosmogony.
Empedocles transforms Hesiod’s divine genealogy into a naturalistic cosmology governed by Love and Strife.
Purification recasts Hesiodic divine justice into a metaphysical law of reincarnation and moral purification.
Prometheus Bound dramatizes the Hesiodic Prometheus episode, expanding and reinterpreting the original mythic material.
Bacchae uses the Hesiodic genealogy of Dionysus and dramatizes divine retribution rooted in Theogony’s cosmic hierarchy.
The Golden Verses transform the Theogony’s externally imposed divine order into a philosophical ethic of inner harmony.
Mirabilia explicitly cites Hesiodic monsters as real-world marvels, using Theogony as a quasi-scientific authority.
Protagoras treats Hesiodic myth as foundational to traditional moral education.
The Symposium philosophically transforms Hesiod’s primordial Eros into a metaphysical engine of ascent and desire.
Gorgias draws on Hesiodic divine justice and relies on Hesiod’s genealogical framework for the myth of postmortem judgment.
The Republic openly cites, critiques, and rewrites Hesiod’s theogonic stories.
Theaetetus reframes Hesiod’s concern with mortal ignorance and divine truth into a philosophical theory of knowledge.
Timaeus restructures Hesiod’s divine cosmogony into a rational philosophical cosmology governed by mathematical order.
De Anima replaces Hesiod’s mythic, genealogical model of divine vitality with a naturalistic definition of soul.
Metaphysics critiques Hesiod’s divine genealogy as an early, inadequate attempt at metaphysics and cosmology.
The Ethics quotes Hesiod and builds its account of virtue atop the Hesiodic framework of divine justice and moderation.
Rhetoric quotes Hesiod directly and treats him as a model of poetic moral authority, drawing on the Theogony’s moral universe.
Poetics explicitly cites Hesiod’s Theogony as the paradigm of genealogical poetry in contrast to Homer’s narrative epic.
Harmonics philosophically parallels the orderly cosmos created by Zeus in Theogony, translating mythic order into musical-scientific order.
Herodotus identifies Hesiod’s Theogony as the canonical Greek account of the gods and uses it as the basis for cross-cultural comparison.
Protagoras reinterprets Hesiod’s justice-centered anthropology as a philosophical theory of moral education.
The Republic reworks the moral core of Works and Days—justice, moderation, labor, anti-hubris—into a philosophical theory of the ideal city.
The Nicomachean Ethics develops Hesiod’s moral instructions into the central framework of Greek virtue ethics.
Rhetoric treats Works and Days as a primary source of ethical maxims and moral examples for persuasion.
Poetics identifies Hesiod as the model of didactic, morally instructive poetry, placing Works and Days at the center of its aesthetic argument.
Metaphysics uses Hesiod as the mythic background against which rational causation evolves.
Antigone embodies the Hesiodic principle that divine justice supersedes human law and punishes hubris.
The Golden Verses mirror Works and Days almost exactly as a moral-didactic guide rooted in justice, moderation, and disciplined living.
The Gortyn Code is the closest legal relative to Dreros, forming a unified picture of early Cretan constitutional law.
Herodotus gives the historical and ethnographic background that contextualizes the Dreros law within early Greek institutional development.
Thucydides reconstructs the type of early polis governance to which the Dreros law belongs.

Aristotle’s Athenian Constitution offers direct conceptual parallels to the institutional logic behind the Dreros law, especially its rotation of magistracies, term limits, and the early evolution of civic accountability.

Aristotle’s Politics provides the theoretical framework explaining why early Greek cities like Dreros imposed strict limits on magistrates, making it a strong comparative match for the inscription’s constitutional logic.
The Delphic Maxims echo the Homeric Hymns’ Apolline moral universe, expressing in compact ethical formulae the same divine order articulated narratively in the hymns.
Pindar’s Odes rework and elevate the divine portraits of the Homeric Hymns, translating hymnographic myth and cult ideology into aristocratic victory poetry.
Aeschylus’ Oresteia dramatizes the same divine justice system the Homeric Hymns outline mythically, transforming hymnographic theology into the foundation of civic order.
Prometheus Bound subverts and interrogates the divine hierarchy presented straightforwardly in the Homeric Hymns, using the same gods to explore the cost of cosmic order.
Medea dramatizes the same divine genealogies and Olympian dynamics framed foundationally in the Homeric Hymns, but turned toward psychological and tragic ends.
Oedipus Rex operates entirely inside the Apolline cosmology articulated in the Homeric Hymns, transforming their divine truth-logic into a tragedy of human ignorance.
Hippolytus dramatizes the divine polarities and cultic identities established in the Homeric Hymns, especially the conflict between Aphrodite’s eros and Artemis’s purity.
The Bacchae is a dramatic re-enactment of the Dionysian divine identity articulated in the Homeric Hymns, showing what happens when a mortal city refuses the god’s hymnic prerogatives.
Orphic Fragments share the same mythic architecture as the Homeric Hymns, presenting alternative or esoteric versions of the divine stories the Hymns canonize for mainstream cult.
The Orphic Hymns mirror the structure and divine profiles of the Homeric Hymns, offering an esoteric counterpart to their mainstream cultic theology.
The Golden Verses encode the moral side of the divine order presented in the Homeric Hymns, expressing hymnic theology as disciplined ethical instruction.
The Delos temple dedication materializes the cultic world established in the Homeric Hymns, continuing their Artemis/Apollo-centered sacred tradition in stone.
The Symposium translates the divine erotic power portrayed in the Homeric Hymns into a philosophical theory of love, using the same gods and mythic logic in a new register.
The Republic uses the divine portraits of the Homeric Hymns as its baseline, then reworks and restricts them to construct a philosophical theology suitable for an ideal city.
Phaedrus transforms the mythic-divine psychology of the Homeric Hymns into a philosophical model of love, beauty, and inspiration.
Critias retools the divine genealogy and cosmic authority of gods like Poseidon—first formalized in the Homeric Hymns—into a mythic-political narrative about Atlantis.
Timaeus transforms the mythic cosmological order found in the Homeric Hymns into a systematic philosophical cosmology governed by the Demiurge.
Euthyphro draws on the mythic divine behavior articulated in the Homeric Hymns to problematize what “piety” means in a world shaped by such gods.
Metaphysics reframes the divine narratives preserved in the Homeric Hymns as primitive attempts at causal explanation, treating hymnic theology as philosophy’s earliest ancestor.
Empedocles’ On Nature transforms the divine powers and mythic vocabulary of the Homeric Hymns into a philosophical cosmology of elemental forces.
In Purification, Empedocles reshapes hymnic themes of purity, divine justice, and underworld cosmology into a philosophical doctrine of moral reincarnation.
Herodotus’ Histories assumes the divine personalities, cult practices, and sacred geographies first formalized in the Homeric Hymns, transforming hymnic theology into ethnographic narrative.
Gorgias’ Encomium of Helen reworks hymnic divine genealogies and epithets into a rhetorical defense, treating Olympian forces as explanatory mechanisms for human action.

Secondary Name: The Calendar of Cos (Koan Sacred Calendar)
Note: The Koan Sacred Calendar operationalizes the divine identities presented in the Homeric Hymns, turning their mythic portraits into concrete ritual schedules.
Theocritus’ Idylls recycle the divine vocabulary, cult imagery, and epithets of the Homeric Hymns, transporting hymnic theology into a pastoral Hellenistic setting.
Cleanthes’ Hymn to Zeus reformulates the Homeric Hymns’ portrait of Zeus into a stoic theology of cosmic rational order.
The Delian Artemis dedication materializes the mythic cultic world of the Homeric Hymns, affirming their theological framework in historical ritual practice.
Herodotus provides the primary historical narrative for Naucratis, supplying the political, ethnic, and administrative context that the inscriptions embody materially.
Olbia’s inscriptions form the best epigraphic parallel to Naucratis, showing how Greek colonies in foreign lands regulated trade, civic identity, and sanctuaries.
Pindar’s Odes poetically enact the same Apolline ethic of measure, self-mastery, and reverence found in the Delphic Maxims.
Aeschylus’ Oresteia dramatizes Apolline moral principles—purity, justice, and measured civic order—that correspond directly with the ethical worldview of the Delphic Maxims.
Herodotus repeatedly frames political history through the Apolline moral order embodied in the Delphic Maxims, using them as interpretive keys for human fortune and failure.
Plato’s Protagoras engages the same ethical foundations—justice, reverence, civic virtue, the Seven Sages—that structure the Delphic Maxims’ Apolline moral program
The Symposium rearticulates Delphic ethical maxims—especially moderation and self-knowledge—through a philosophical theory of ordered desire and ascent toward the divine.
Thucydides provides sober historical context in which the Delphic Oracle functioned as a political and religious guide, demonstrating the Maxims’ practical civic backdrop.
The Golden Verses are the closest ethical analogue to the Delphic Maxims in antiquity — nearly a sister-text in form and content.
Apology provides the clearest philosophical witness to Delphi’s moral authority, placing the Maxims’ ethos into the heart of Socratic self-examination.
The Phaedrus embeds “Know thyself” into its philosophical core, making it one of the clearest literary extensions of Delphic ethical doctrine.
Xenophon treats “Know thyself” as a central ethical rule of life, making Memorabilia the clearest and most didactic prose extension of Delphic moral tradition.
Aristotle translates the Delphic ethos into a systematic ethical theory; he does not quote the Maxims but builds their logic into the core of classical virtue ethics.
This Platonic dialogue is the most explicit ancient commentary on Parmenides’ fragments, reproducing and interrogating his Eleatic metaphysical claims line-by-line.

The Sophist is Plato’s direct, programmatic correction of Parmenides, redefining not-being as difference rather than absolute nonexistence — one of the most important philosophical engagements with the Eleatic tradition.

The Theaetetus uses Parmenidean Being vs. Becoming as the foundational philosophical schema for its inquiry into whether knowledge = perception; it is a major indirect engagement with Eleatic metaphysics.
The Timaeus is Plato’s cosmological counter-model to Eleatic Being: it asserts that becoming is real, caused, and structured, effectively rejecting Parmenides’ denial of change.
On Non-Being is the sharpest ancient rejection of Parmenides: a formal, logical dismantling of Eleatic monism and its epistemological commitments.

Antigone is the purest tragic parallel to the Oresteia: a relentless confrontation between divine law and human authority, exposing the ruin that follows when sacred burial justice collides with civic decree.

The Gold Tablets are the eschatological completion of the Orphic Fragments: the clearest ritual articulation of Orphic doctrine, revealing the soul’s path in the afterlife through direct theological continuity.
The Orphic Hymns are the liturgical echo of the Orphic Fragments: a ritualized preservation of Orphic cosmogony, divine epithets, and initiatory theology in hymnic form.
Empedocles’ Purification is the philosophical transformation of Orphic theology: a reincarnation and purity doctrine recast as cosmic-natural philosophy.

Empedocles’ On Nature is a cosmological cousin to the Orphic Fragments: a mythic cycle of unity and dissolution that mirrors Orphic creation patterns without adopting their initiatory or eschatological doctrine.
Timaeus is Plato’s cosmological reply to Empedocles, reshaping the four roots and cosmic cycle into a crafted, rational universe governed by necessity and divine design.
On Generation and Corruption is the classical analysis of Empedocles’ physics: Aristotle’s precise reconstruction and critique of the elemental mixture and the cycle driven by Love and Strife.
The Gold Tablets are the ritual counterpart to Purification: an eschatological guidebook expressing exactly the same doctrine of divine exile, ritual purity, and final release from reincarnation.
The Phaedo is Plato’s philosophical restatement of Purification: a rationalized account of the soul’s exile, purification, and transmigratory ascent to divine company.
The Decree from Thasos is the closest structural twin to the Chios decree: another Athenian imperial inscription fixing allied obligations through identical legal and fiscal formulae.

Secondary Name: Athenian Tribute Lists & Financial Records (Delian League)
Note: The Tribute Lists provide the fiscal infrastructure behind the Chios decree, revealing how Athens enforced and recorded allied obligations within its imperial system.
The Delos control decree stands beside the Chios decree as an archetype of Athenian administrative oversight, fixing jurisdiction and civic obligations through identical legal formulae.

Secondary Name: Diplomatic and Civic Decrees of Rhodes
Note: The Rhodian decrees are parallel civic epigraphy, mirroring the Chios decree’s formulaic diplomacy, oath-taking, and statutory obligations between poleis.
Bacchae is the Dionysian counterpart to Prometheus Bound: a tragic demonstration of divine absolutism crushing mortal resistance under the logic of cosmic necessity.
Gorgias’ Encomium reframes the divine compulsion of Prometheus Bound into rhetorical theory, treating force and necessity as the same irresistible powers embodied by Kratos and Bia.
Cleanthes’ Hymn to Zeus is the philosophical inversion of Prometheus Bound: a vision of Zeus’ total rule rendered as rational cosmic justice rather than divine tyranny.
Crito is the philosophical inversion of Antigone: a rigorous defense of obedience to civic law over personal moral conviction.
Euthyphro is the philosophical anatomy of Antigone’s dilemma: a dissection of divine law, piety, and moral authority.
Apology is the Socratic parallel to Antigone: the claim that divine obligation outranks mortal authority.
Thucydides is Herodotus’ sharpest successor: a methodological countermodel that defines the boundary between inquiry and political realism.
Mirabilia is the stripped-down descendant of Herodotus’ wondrous ethnography — a genre built from the curiosities and marvels he first embedded inside historical inquiry.

Secondary Name: Athenian Tribute Lists & Financial Records (Delian League)
Note: The Tribute Lists are the financial mirror of the Thasos decree, the record of the very imperial machinery the decree legally enforces.
The Delos decree is a structural twin to the Thasos decree, another Athenian imperial inscription enforcing jurisdiction, obedience, and civic control.

Secondary Name: Diplomatic and Civic Decrees of Rhodes
Note: The Rhodian decrees are the best comparative corpus for the Thasos decree: parallel treaty-language revealing the shared diplomatic grammar of the Greek interstate world.

Primary Name: Athenian Tribute Lists & Financial Records (Delian League)
Note: The Delos decree supplies the legal framework that the Tribute Lists document financially.

Primary Name: Athenian Tribute Lists & Financial Records (Delian League)
Note: Thucydides gives the political logic behind the Tribute Lists: the imperial ideology that turns financial assessments into coercive power.
Crito philosophically reframes Oedipus’ dilemma: the problem of moral responsibility when intention and outcome violently diverge.
Euthyphro dissects the theological and moral architecture of Oedipus’ guilt—what makes an unintentional act impious.
In the Poetics, Oedipus Rex becomes Aristotle’s absolute paradigm of tragedy— the perfect fusion of error, reversal, and recognition that defines what tragic art is.
Bacchae is the dark twin of Hippolytus—Euripides’ second anatomy of a mortal annihilated for defying a god’s honor.
Gorgias’ analysis of eros as divine compulsion provides a rhetorical skeleton key to understanding Phaedra’s fatal passion in Hippolytus.
Aristotle treats Hippolytus as the example of a misbuilt recognition scene, making it a rare and explicit diagnostic case in the Poetics.
Thucydides provides the political and imperial backdrop that makes the Athenian Control Decree on Delos intelligible: imperial cult-management as realpolitik.
Gorgias’ theory of divine persuasion and overpowering eros maps cleanly onto Dionysian possession in the Bacchae.
Plato’s Gorgias dismantles the Encomium’s theory of persuasion, treating Gorgias’ absolution of Helen as the archetype of rhetoric’s moral danger.
Phaedrus reframes Helen’s “eros compelled her” argument into a philosophical anatomy of divine madness and rhetorical power.
Republic answers the Encomium with moral seriousness: persuasion without truth corrupts the soul and destroys political order.
The Rhetoric is the classical world’s explicit corrective to the Encomium: persuasion becomes an analyzable technique, not a metaphysical force.
Plato’s Parmenides is the Eleatic fortress that On Non-Being tries to blow open, turning strict ontology into impossibility.
The Sophist is Plato’s philosophical counter-strike: a reconstruction of non-being precisely where Gorgias had annihilated it.
Theaetetus charts the epistemic collapse Gorgias embraces, showing how easily knowledge dissolves into shifting appearances.
Protagoras relativizes truth; Gorgias turns that relativism into a metaphysical vacuum.

Plato’s Gorgias presents a deliberately distorted, straw-man version of the historical sophist, using him as a foil to attack sophistic rhetoric and reinforce his own moral program—a polemic worlds removed from the actual arguments of On Non-Being.
Metaphysics is Aristotle’s answer to Gorgias: a defense of being and logic against the total collapse of ontology.
Demosthenes’ Against Meidias displays parallel techniques of cultivating moral indignation and civic outrage, illuminating Lysias’ own rhetorical posture.
Isocrates’ Areopagiticus lays out the moral-legal framework of adultery and justified retaliation that underpins Lysias’ argument in On the Murder of Eratosthenes.
Xenophon’s Hellenica serves as the direct historical continuation of Thucydides, carrying the Peloponnesian narrative forward from the very moment Thucydides’ account breaks off.
Xenophon’s Anabasis echoes Thucydides’ analysis of leadership and military failure by depicting how armies collapse or survive through strategic intelligence and internal order.
Isocrates’ Panegyricus offers a moralized vision of Panhellenic unity that stands in sharp contrast to the cold realpolitik Thucydides assigns to Athenian imperialism.
Aristotle’s Politics systematizes the dynamics of civil war and imperialism that Thucydides illustrates narratively in the Peloponnesian War.
Xenophon’s Memorabilia corroborates the Socratic commitment to lawful obedience that Plato dramatizes in the Crito.
Aristotle’s Nicomachean Ethics systematizes the moral principles—justice, non-retaliation, and the primacy of the soul—that Socrates applies concretely in the Crito.
Xenophon’s Memorabilia reinforces the rational conception of piety that Plato begins to articulate in the Euthyphro.
Aristotle’s Nicomachean Ethics elaborates the rational virtue theory that challenges the divine-command assumptions interrogated in Euthyphro.
Aristotle’s Metaphysics presents a rational, non-anthropomorphic divinity that destabilizes Euthyphro’s simplistic theology.
Aristotle’s De Anima offers a philosophical account of the soul’s divine rationality that contrasts with Euthyphro’s mythic assumptions.
Xenophon’s Memorabilia offers an independent defense of Socrates’ virtue that complements the portrait of integrity in Plato’s Apology.
Xenophon’s Hellenica provides the political climate of fear and instability that contextualizes Socrates’ prosecution in the Apology.
Isocrates’ Antidosis imitates Socrates’ persecuted-sage posture from the Apology, though his professed “trial” is a performative fiction.
Aristotle’s Nicomachean Ethics articulates the moral psychology and virtue concepts underlying Socrates’ ethical defense in the Apology.
Xenophon’s Hellenica exposes the Greek disunity and Persian influence that the Panegyricus urges Athens to transcend through Panhellenic leadership.
Xenophon’s Anabasis illustrates the humiliating consequences of Greek disunity abroad that Isocrates’ Panegyricus seeks to remedy with a unified Hellenic program.
Xenophon’s Memorabilia, shaped by the same anti-sophistic suspicion found in Plato, independently probes the sophists’ claim to teach virtue, mirroring the central dispute of Protagoras.
Xenophon’s Memorabilia preserves Socratic discussions of eros and self-mastery that illuminate the ethical foundation of Plato’s Symposium.
Xenophon’s Hellenica supplies the historical backdrop for Alcibiades’ persona, enhancing the political resonance of his portrait in the Symposium.
Aristotle’s Nicomachean Ethics elaborates the concepts of love, nobility, and contemplative desire that structure the Symposium’s theory of eros.
Aristotle’s Metaphysics offers a cosmological version of eros as desire for the divine, echoing the metaphysical climax of the Symposium.
Xenophon’s Memorabilia gives an independent Socratic critique of sophists that reinforces the ethical attack on rhetoric in Plato’s Gorgias.
Xenophon’s Hellenica reveals the political decay caused by persuasive power without virtue, the very pathology condemned in the Gorgias.
Aristotle’s Rhetoric anatomizes the persuasive techniques that Plato condemns in the Gorgias as morally empty and politically toxic.
Aristotle’s Sophistical Refutations lays out the deceptive argumentative moves dramatized by Socrates’ opponents in the Gorgias.
Xenophon’s Memorabilia preserves the practical Socratic ethics that the Republic transforms into the philosophical and political program of the just city.
Isocrates’ Antidosis presents an ethical paideia that mirrors the Republic’s pedagogical ascent, though without its metaphysical foundations.
Aristotle’s Politics provides the foundational critique of the Republic’s political blueprint, dissecting its unity, education, and communal arrangements.
Aristotle’s Politics provides the analytic categories for the spontaneous constitutional practices Xenophon depicts in the Anabasis.
Xenophon’s Memorabilia preserves Socratic teachings on eros and soul-care that illuminate the ethical foundations of the Phaedrus.
Isocrates’ Antidosis articulates a moral rhetoric that parallels the Phaedrus’ ideal of a philosophically grounded art of persuasion.
Aristotle’s Rhetoric develops the psychological art of persuasion that the Phaedrus defines as true rhetoric.
Aristotle’s Metaphysics directly engages the One–Many puzzles introduced in the Parmenides, offering the ancient world’s most influential response to Plato’s dialectic.
Aristotle’s Physics addresses the Eleatic paradoxes that form the conceptual backdrop of the Parmenides, especially the puzzles of unity, plurality, and motion.
Aristotle’s De Anima reworks the unity-versus-multiplicity issues that the Parmenides dramatizes in purely logical form.
Aristotle’s On Generation and Corruption develops a theory of change that answers Eleatic objections dramatized in the Parmenides.
The Organon supplies the formal logic of predication needed to analyze the paradoxes staged in Plato’s Parmenides.
Aristotle’s Nicomachean Ethics echoes the Parmenides in its explorations of whether virtue is one or many.
Xenophon’s Memorabilia preserves the Socratic method of definition-testing that structures the epistemic inquiry of the Theaetetus.
Isocrates’ Antidosis articulates a civic conception of knowledge that forms the real-world foil to the Theaetetus’ philosophical analysis of what knowledge is.
Isocrates’ Areopagiticus reinforces the Theaetetus’ distinction between genuine knowledge and the superficial pseudo-knowledge of public speakers.
The Organon formalizes the method of definition-testing that structures the Theaetetus.
Aristotle’s Physics offers the anti-Heraclitean arguments needed to evaluate the flux doctrine tested in the Theaetetus.
Aristotle’s On Generation and Corruption supplies metaphysical clarifications that resolve the flux-based epistemic paradoxes of the Theaetetus.
Plato’s Phaedo dramatizes the same Socratic moral discipline that Xenophon’s Memorabilia records in practical, everyday form.
Plato’s Sophist philosophically attacks the sophists whose moral failures Xenophon exposes narratively in the Memorabilia.
Plato’s Timaeus provides the metaphysical teleology that Xenophon attributes to Socrates as a practical ethical doctrine.
Aristotle’s Ethics gives the practical moral theory that Phaedo expresses through Socrates’ purificatory ideal.
Isocrates’ Areopagiticus diagnoses the moral collapse that provides the political backdrop to the Phaedo.
Isocrates’ Areopagiticus condemns the political influence of deceptive rhetors whom the Sophist defines philosophically.
Aristotle’s Rhetoric systematizes the persuasive illusions that Plato’s Sophist critiques as the essence of sophistry.
Aristotle’s Politics theorizes the constitutional cycle that Critias casts as the mythic rise and fall of Atlantis.
Aristotle’s Metaphysics provides the philosophical alternative to the Demiurge-driven cosmogony of the Timaeus.
Aristotle’s Physics systematizes the natural processes the Timaeus describes in mythic-scientific form.
Aristoxenus’ Harmonics supplies the musical mathematics that parallels the cosmological mathematics of the Timaeus.
Plato’s Letters expose the political corruption and failed leadership that Isocrates seeks to reverse in the Areopagiticus.
Demosthenes’ On the Embassy anatomizes the same diplomatic treachery that Plato’s Letters recount autobiographically.
Aristotle’s De Anima provides the psychological theory of the soul that the Orphic Tablets ritualize in eschatological form.
The Orphic Hymns articulate the theological and cosmological system whose afterlife ritual the Gold Tablets operationalize.
The Pythagorean Golden Verses teach the ethical purification that prepares for the soul’s journey described in the Orphic Tablets.
Cleanthes’ Hymn presents a rational cosmic order analogous to the divine order presupposed by the Orphic Tablets’ eschatology.
The Orphic Hymns outline a mythic-cosmic ontology that parallels, in symbolic form, the first-principle concerns of Aristotle’s Metaphysics.
The Pythagorean Golden Verses assert a numerically ordered cosmos whose ethical and metaphysical structure echoes the causal architecture explored in the Metaphysics.
Cleanthes’ Hymn expresses a Stoic cosmic reason structurally parallel to the unmoved mover and teleological order developed in Aristotle’s Metaphysics.
Aristoxenus’ Harmonics offers a mathematical-cosmic order that provides an indirect analogue to Aristotle’s inquiry into the principles of being.
The Orphic Hymns provide a mythic cosmology of natural processes that mirrors, in symbolic form, the causal analysis of the Physics.
The Pythagorean Golden Verses describe a numerically ordered cosmos whose harmonious structure indirectly resonates with Aristotle’s account of natural order in the Physics.
Cleanthes’ Hymn articulates a Stoic doctrine of divine causation and cosmic motion that parallels the natural causality studied in Aristotle’s Physics.
Aristoxenus’ Harmonics offers a mathematical account of order and motion that indirectly parallels Aristotle’s natural philosophy in the Physics.
Aeschines’ Against Timarchus shares the same civic-moral framework as Against Meidias, using shame and public ethics to define who is fit to act in the polis.
Aeschines’ Against Ctesiphon parallels Against Meidias in its use of civic virtue, legal precedent, and character attacks to define proper public conduct.
On the Crown offers the inverse ideological vision of To Philip, depicting Philip not as savior but as the tyrant whose ambitions threaten Greek freedom.
Politics supplies the philosophical backdrop for the idealized, beneficent kingship that To Philip urges Philip to embody.
On the Embassy intersects with Against Timarchus by recounting the same diplomatic events that Aeschines uses to build his moral case against political incompetence.
On the Crown is the counter-polemic that challenges the very moral criteria for public life articulated in Against Timarchus.
Against Ctesiphon revisits and counter-interprets the same embassies that On the Embassy narrates, turning Demosthenes’ accusations into an indictment of his credibility.
Politics provides the philosophical framework describing the democratic failures that On the Embassy presents in historical detail.
Theophrastus’ plant treatise parallels History of Animals as the plant-focused continuation of Aristotelian empirical biology.
Against Ctesiphon embodies the democratic dysfunctions—demagoguery, corruption, civic decay—that Politics analyzes in philosophical form.
On the Crown provides a rhetorical-historical portrait of the demagoguery and factionalism that Politics treats as structural weaknesses of democracies.
In Harmonics, Aristoxenus being Aristotle's student employs Peripatetic definitional and classificatory method derived from the logical framework of the Organon.

Aristoxenus employs the same Peripatetic analytical method and much of the same technical vocabulary that Aristotle systematizes in Poetics, with both works reflecting the shared intellectual framework of the Lyceum.
On the Crown confronts and reverses the accusations of Against Ctesiphon, presenting the same events through a diametrically opposed political and ethical lens.
The Athenian Constitution provides the institutional and historical framework that explains the civic dysfunction dramatized in Against Ctesiphon.
The Athenian Constitution provides the institutional explanation for the democratic dysfunction that On the Crown portrays from inside the courtroom.
